KAY N. LARDIE
Kay felt that If the project is going to be successful it irould have to
be underwritten by some outside funds« She suggested that they would have
several samples of kinescopes or video tapes that might be usedo She is also
writing a pamphlet for a national organization titled "’’Utilization of Tele¬
vision in the Classroom"* I wrote to see if this pamphlet was something that
could be included in the NAEB distribution plans but have not received an answer,
Some of the things that they are using in Detroit are: 1) a kit prepared for
teachers who are to present a telecast, giving examples of good and poor visual
materials, a list of do’s and don’t’s and a sample script, etc®; 2) a video
tape for presentation to the Board of Education which was also used at a meeting
of all the principals in the city. The video tape had excerpts from nine
programs, five minutes each, together with an opening and a summary of production
techniques. The entire tape ran 5>3 minutes5 and 3) a kit of materials giving
samples of each bulletin that goes out from the Radio-Television Office to the
schools.
While all of these are directed at the Detroit needs, Kay felt that they
would be helpful in other areas,
JAMES F. MACANDREW
Jim said, "I am in complete agreement that the promotion of good utilise-
practices is a highly important aspect of school television and one which most
of us ignore throu^i lade of manpower and money,
"Although we include some suggestions on utilization in our manuals, they
are superficial and not in any way what I should like them to be,
"At a meeting in Cambridge less than three weeks ago, (letter dated March
31, I960) representatives of seven states agreed that a combined attack on the
subject of more effective utilization information was very important. While
I am not in a position to do anything constructive at the moment because of
other pressures, I shall be very happy to talk with you in Columbus and make
any contribution I can,"
For more information about the Cambridge meeting, see Keith Nighbert’s
reply below,
DAVID W. MARXER
David said, "We consider utilization one of the major aspects of educational
broadcasting and want to cooperate in the development of effective materials
for this purpose. For the past several years we have worked on in-school TV
utilization with steadily increasing success. We attribute this success to the
gradual development of a sense of involvement of our consumer group. Kits
specifically designed for utilization workshops could be of tremendous value and
would certainly reduce the strain on those responsible for organizing said
workshops. We always attempt to collect pertinent publications for distribution
at our workshops but invariably miss some of the most pertinent ones and include
